intro: Brassica leptocarpa, commonly known as narrowleaf mustard, is an annual herbaceous plant native to North America. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes many economically important crops such as cabbage and broccoli. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm, with slender, branching stems and alternate leaves that are usually narrow and lance-shaped. Its small, yellow flowers are arranged in racemes and bloom in the spring, followed by the production of long, slender pods containing seeds. This plant is often found in disturbed soils and is considered a weed in agricultural settings.
